contentrichtext.text: The '''Water Integrator''' was an early [[analog computer]] built in the [[Soviet Union]] in 1928.{{Citation needed|date=August 2011}} It functioned by careful manipulation of [[water]] through a room full of interconnected pipes and pumps. The water level in various chambers (with precision to fractions of a [[millimeter]]) represented stored numbers, and the rate of flow between them represented mathematical operations. This machine was capable of solving non-homogeneous [[differential equation]]s. Water analog computers were used in [[USSR]] until the 1980s for large-scale modelling. ==See also== * [[History of computing hardware]] * [[MONIAC Computer]] * [[Fluidics]] ==References== * ISBN 3-528-05757-2 * ISBN 0-309-09630-8 (Both online at google books) {{Refimprove|date=May 2007}} ==External links== * [http://www.blikstein.com/paulo/projects/project_water.html MIT water computer] * [http://translate.google.com/translate?sl=ru&tl=en&js=n&prev=_t&hl=es&ie=UTF-8&layout=2&eotf=1&u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nkj.ru%2Farchive%2Farticles%2F7033%2F Translated article from ''Science and Life'' Russian magazine about water integrators in the Soviet Union] [[Category:One-of-a-kind computers]] [[Category:Early computers]] [[Category:Analog computers]] {{compu-hardware-stub}}
